page.title: 01Head of Cerne River Valley
page.content: This grid is set on part of the escarpment of the North Dorset Downs, which rises to a height at the Little Minterne Hill of 261mtrs.The area has a chalk geology and consequently has little surface drainage. The only example of flurial processes atwork is the River Cerne which has eroded its base in its upper stages, to leave upstanding escapments on either side f the valley. This has meant that in the valley arable farming takes place, while the escarpments only allow rough grazing for sheep and cattle. The arable fields are enclosed by hedges, while the escarpments need less enclosure. The farms in this area are of commercial nature, they are highly mechanised and hence do not need many hands. Hence this area employs a small agricultural workforce and has a low population density.
